The cells of C. brevis are known to form aggregates or "congregations," which is the basis for its species name. These aggregates can contain numerous individual cells that are held together by an extracellular matrix. This unique cell arrangement and aggregation behavior is considered a distinctive feature of the species.

C. brevis is classified within the family Hyphomicrobiaceae and is believed to be related to other bacteria within the order Rhizobiales. The natural habitat of C. brevis is not well-characterized, but it has been isolated from various environmental samples, including soil and freshwater sediments.

Limited information is available about the specific physiological and metabolic properties of C. brevis, as it is a relatively understudied bacterial species. Further research is needed to fully understand its ecological roles, potential applications, and the genetic and molecular mechanisms underlying its unique aggregation behavior.
